Based on my search results, here's information about Polish adaptations of Tolkien's "The Hobbit" in theater, radio, film, and Polish culture:

## Theater Adaptations

The Polish premiere of the theatrical production "Hobbit" based on J.R.R. Tolkien's novel took place on May 11 at the Dramatic Theater in Białystok. The theater acquired a three-year license from the USA for this production - as the only theater in Poland and one of the first in Europe, "if not the first".

The play's director is Grzegorz Suski, who - as he said - had been thinking about producing "The Hobbit" for many years, but the matter always fell through due to the license. The cast includes 33 actors. Suski clarified, "It will be +The Hobbit+, meaning Tolkien's book, but not some abbreviated version, rather a properly adapted stage version of this book" and that they decided to make the play "as Tolkien wanted, without any references to modernity, to current events".

Additionally, At the Jaracza Theater in Łódź, in an adaptation and direction by Grzegorz Suski, both the youngest and older viewers will find themselves. The performance filled with songs, costumes from the Hobbit world, props of elves or dwarves is an adventure and journey.

In 2015 in Wilamowice, there was a premiere of the play Hobbit. Hejn ȧn cyryk, based on fragments of Tolkien's text translated into the Wymysorys language.

## Film Adaptations

While not specifically Polish productions, the Peter Jackson film trilogy has been popular in Poland. The Hobbit is an American-New Zealand film trilogy production, combining the fantasy genre with adventure film. It is a film adaptation of the novel The Hobbit, or There and Back Again by J.R.R. Tolkien, introduced to cinemas as a prequel to The Lord of the Rings film trilogy. The producer, co-screenwriter and director of the entire project is Peter Jackson.

## Polish Translation History

The Polish edition was published in 1960 in the translation by Maria Skibniewska. In Poland, a total of 3 translations were published, chronologically after Skibniewska they were Paulina Braiter-Ziemkiewicz (1997) and Andrzej Polkowski (2002).

## Historical Context of Adaptations

In those years, The Hobbit received many school adaptations - often with songs written specifically for the play. Tolkien on one hand expressed prejudice against any form of "children's theater," but on the other hand kept in mind whether the play had artistic value or not. He agreed when the play was to have only school audiences, and opposed projects that would become more public.

The search results show that Polish cultural engagement with Tolkien's "The Hobbit" has been significant, particularly in theatrical adaptations, with the Białystok production being especially notable as one of the first officially licensed productions in Europe. The work has also been adapted in various forms including translations and regional language versions, demonstrating its impact on Polish culture.
